committees.title: General Purposes Committee
committees.purposeSuggested: Suggested: Handles a range of general delegated matters not otherwise assigned to another committee, often including procedural/governance or miscellaneous functions.

committees.title: Cabinet
committees.purpose: The Cabinet comprises seven councillors including the Leader of the Council who chairs its meetings. It has responsibility for the day-to-day decisions on council functions and makes recommendations to full Council on the major policy plans and the budget and Council Tax. There is a Cabinet Member for each of the following Council services: · Regeneration · Resources · Environment · Housing · Planning · Community Engagement · Culture and Leisure The Leader of the Council is appointed by full Council at its annual meeting and the Leader appoints the Cabinet. The Cabinet is held to account by the Overview and Scrutiny Committee. The Council has a Liberal Democrat minority Administration and Cabinet comprises 7 Liberal Democrat Councillors.

committees.title: Constitution
committees.purposeSuggested: Suggested: Maintains and oversees the Councilâ€™s Constitution and associated governance arrangements, ensuring it remains current and fit for purpose.

committees.title: Council
committees.purpose: All 39 councillors meet together as the full Council, presided over by the Mayor, eight times a year. Here Councillors decide the overall policies and set the budget each year. The main roles of the full Council are: -To appoint the Mayor and Sheriff/Deputy Mayor for the forthcoming municipal year -To appoint and remove the Leader of the Council -To set the budget and level of Council Tax -To approve the policy framework. The policy framework is the collection of plans and strategies that dictate the Council’s overall policy direction At Council meetings there is opportunity for all Councillors to ask questions of the Leader and Cabinet Members. The Council also debates Notices of Motion, which are requests from Councillors for an issue of city-wide importance to be discussed and a decision to be made. Meetings of the Council are open to the public except where personal or confidential matters are being discussed.

committees.title: Saintbridge Recreation Ground Management Committee
committees.purposeSuggested: Suggested: Manages the relevant trust/asset and associated governance, including oversight of operations, funding, and stewardship responsibilities.

committees.title: Saintbridge Trust
committees.purposeSuggested: Suggested: Manages the relevant trust/asset and associated governance, including oversight of operations, funding, and stewardship responsibilities.

committees.title: Senior Appointments Committee
committees.purposeSuggested: Suggested: Oversees the recruitment/appointment process for senior officers and makes appointment recommendations/decisions in line with the Councilâ€™s constitution.

committees.title: Standards Hearing Panel
committees.purposeSuggested: Suggested: Supports and determines matters relating to member conduct and standards, including hearings/panels where applicable.

committees.title: Joint Overview and Scrutiny Review Panel - Gloucestershire Airport
committees.purpose: The Joint Overview and Scrutiny Review Panel consists of a cohort of Overview and Scrutiny Committee Members from Gloucester City Council and Cheltenham Borough Council. At the time the Joint Overview and Scrutiny Review Panel was convened, Gloucestershire Airport was a jointly-owned asset of both Councils. In June 2025, both Councils approved a decision to sell Gloucestershire Airport to a recommended bidder. As a large local employer and contributor to the local economy, Overview and Scrutiny Committee Members have retained an interest in the current operations of Gloucestershire Airport, as well as the future of the organisation. The Joint Overview and Scrutiny Review Panel propose to meet on two occasions, initially to consider the latest financial and operational updates from the airport so that they can understand the position facing the potential new owner. Once the sale has taken place, a secondary session will be held to look ahead to the future of Gloucestershire Airport under its new ownership.

committees.title: Overview and Scrutiny Committee
committees.purpose: The Overview and Scrutiny Committee co-ordinates scrutiny at Gloucester City Council. It conducts both pre- and post-scrutiny of Cabinet decisions, and commissions Task & Finish Groups to investigate specific policy areas. Its main responsibilities can be summarised as follows: Co-ordinating and leading scrutiny of Cabinet decisions. Acting as a ‘critical friend’ for Cabinet. Tracking the progress of recommendations made by Task & Finish groups once they have received a Cabinet response Monitoring the Forward Plan and deciding which policy areas to scrutinise Managing overall scrutiny work plan Scrutiny of bodies external to Gloucester City Council.

committees.title: Audit and Governance Committee
committees.purposeSuggested: Suggested: Oversees governance, risk, internal controls, and audit arrangements; reviews assurances and compliance on key corporate matters.

committees.title: Licensing and Enforcement Committee
committees.purpose: The Licensing and Enforcement Committee is responsible for carrying out functions in relation to private hire vehicles; Hackney Carriages; gaming; entertainment; food, street trading and miscellaneous licensing. It also oversees the activities of the Licensing Sub-Committee.

committees.title: Licensing and Enforcement Sub-Committee
committees.purpose: The Licensing and Enforcement Sub-Committee is responsible for enforcement matters. Meetings will be called as required and the membership will comprise a minimum of three and a maximum of seven Members from the Licensing and Enforcement Committee membership.

committees.title: Licensing Sub-Committee
committees.purpose: The Licensing Sub-Committee is responsible for functions relating to Licenses for the sale of alcohol.

committees.title: Planning Committee
committees.purpose: Purpose of the Planning Committee Most planning applications received by the council are decided by a planning officer. However, some applications are decided at the monthly planning committee meetings which normally take place the first Tuesday of each month. These are usually high-profile planning applications which have created a lot of public interest. The planning officers prepare a detailed report for each application to be considered by the committee and these reports are contained in the committee agenda published five working days before the meeting. All reports are available on the link above on browse meetings and agendas for this committee. Updates to the agenda papers are published prior to the meeting and there may be a final update for members to read on the day of the meeting. Members of the public can attend Planning Committees and arrangements for public speaking are set out below. Occasionally, there may be an "exempt" item which needs to be decided in closed session and the Chairman will announce this at the start of the meeting. Public Speaking at the Planning Committee We encourage public involvement in the planning process and members of the public have the opportunity to put their views on a planning proposal direct to the planning committee. Only individuals who have made written representations will be eligible to speak. If you would like to register to speak, please contact us on 01452 396203 or 01452 396158, or email democratic.services@gloucester.gov.uk any time after the publication of the agenda but by no later than 17.00 on the day before the Planning Committee meeting. Registering to speak will not guarantee an opportunity to address the Committee. This is because with some applications there may be many requests to speak from the same viewpoint. In this situation we ask that a single speaker represents the group. The onus is upon the parties concerned to communicate with each other and agree who should act as the spokesperson. If an agreement on a spokesperson is not reached, the speaking slot will be given to the first registered speaker. The Chairman will invite the registered speaker to speak for 5 minutes to outline their views. This time limit will be strictly enforced.
